Second order implicit differentiation

We sometimes need to obtain the second derivative \( \dfrac{d^2y}{dx^2}\) for a function defined implicitly.

Example

Obtain \( \dfrac{dy}{dx} \) and \( \dfrac{d^2y}{dx^2}\) at the point \( (4, 2)\) on the curve defined by the equation \[ x^2 - xy - y^2 - 2y = 0\]

Solution

Firstly we obtain \( \dfrac{dy}{dx} \) by differentiating the equation implicitly and then evaluate it at \( (4, 2)\).

We have \[ 2x -x\dfrac{dy}{dx} - y -2y\dfrac{dy}{dx} -2\dfrac{dy}{dx} = 0 \hspace{4cm} (1)\] from which \[ \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{2x - y}{x + 2y + 2} \hspace{5cm} (2) \] so at \( (4,2)\), \[ \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{6}{10} = \dfrac{3}{5}. \] to obtain the second derivative \( \dfrac{d^2y}{dx^2}\) it is easier to use \( (1) \) than \( (2) \) becuase the latter is a quotient. We simplify \( (1)\) first: \[ 2x - y - (x + 2y + 2)\dfrac{dy}{dx} = 0. \hspace{5cm} (3)\] We will have to use the product rule to differentiate the third term here.

Hence differentiating \( (3) \) with respect to \(x\): \[ 2 - \dfrac{dy}{dx} - (x + 2y + 2) \dfrac{d^2y}{dx^2} - (1 + 2\dfrac{dy}{dx})\dfrac{dy}{dx} = 0\] or \[ 2 - 2\dfrac{dy}{dx} - 2\left( \dfrac{dy}{dx} \right)^2 - (x + 2y + 2) \dfrac{d^2y}{dx^2} = 0. \hspace{4cm} (4)\] Note carefully that the third term here, \( \left( \dfrac{dy}{dx} \right)^2\), is the square of the first derivative. It should not be confused with the second derivative denoted by \( \dfrac{d^2y}{dx^2}\).

Finally, at \( (4,2)\), where \(\dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{3}{5}\) we obtain from \( (4) \): \[ 2 - 2\left(\dfrac{3}{5}\right) - 2\left(\dfrac{9}{25}\right) - (4+4+2)\dfrac{d^2y}{dx^2} = 0\] from which \[ \dfrac{d^2y}{dx^2} = \dfrac{1}{125}\] at \( (4,2)\).
